title: Tamal de Cazuela (Mexican Tamale Pie) With Black Bean Filling Recipe
full_text:
Tamal de Cazuela (Mexican Tamale Pie) With Black Bean Filling Recipe
Close
Jump to recipe
Prep
25 mins
Cook
75 mins
Active
60 mins
Chilling Time
45 mins
Total
2 hrs 25 mins
Serves
6
to 8 servings
Cook Mode
(Keep screen awake)
Ingredients
For the Masa:
1
pound
(
3
cups
)
masa harina para tamales
(see notes)
3
cups
homemade
or store-bought
low-sodium chicken stock
or
water
6
ounces
(
3/4
cup
) cold
lard
or
Crisco
2
teaspoons
kosher salt
2
teaspoons
baking powder
For the Filling (see notes):
2
ancho chiles
, stemmed and seeded
1
cup
low-sodium chicken broth
2
tablespoons
lard
or
vegetable oil
1
medium
white onion
, chopped
3
medium
cloves garlic
, chopped
4
cups
cooked black beans
(from
four
15-ounce cans
or
2/3
pound
dried black beans
simmered until tender)
Kosher salt
Nonstick cooking spray
or
vegetable oil
, for greasing
Hot sauce
and
salsa verde
, for serving
Directions
In a large mixing bowl, combine masa harina and broth.
Serious Eats / Daniel Gritzer
Stir until thoroughly incorporated.
Serious Eats / Daniel Gritzer
Combine lard, salt, and baking powder and, using an electric mixer, beat at medium-high speed until lightly whipped, about 1 minute.
Serious Eats / Daniel Gritzer
Add 1/4 of the re-hydrated masa at a time to the lard, beating between additions until thoroughly incorporated. The masa should be soft and spreadable, with a hummus-like texture.
Serious Eats / Daniel Gritzer
Cover masa with plastic and refrigerate for 1 hour.
Serious Eats / Daniel Gritzer
Meanwhile, For the Filling:
Microwave ancho chiles until fragrant and pliable, 15 to 30 seconds. Transfer to a microwave-safe bowl or measuring cup, add broth, cover tightly with plastic wrap, and microwave on high power until barely simmering, about 3 minutes. Let steep for at least 5 minutes. Using a blender or immersion blender, blend until smooth.
In a skillet, heat lard over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add onion and garlic and cook until softened, about 3 minutes. Add beans and cook until heated through. Using a potato masher, bean masher, or wooden spoon, mash beans to form a chunky purée. Stir in ancho mixture and cook, stirring, until thickened, about 5 minutes.
Serious Eats / Daniel Gritzer
Assembly and Baking:
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Remove masa from refrigerator, discard plastic, and re-whip, adding water one tablespoon at a time, if necessary, to return it to original hummus-like texture. Lightly grease a 12-inch cast iron skillet or 3-quart casserole dish with cooking spray or oil, wiping up any excess.
Serious Eats / Daniel Gritzer
Scrape 2/3 of masa into skillet and press to form an even thin layer on bottom and edge of pan.
Serious Eats / Daniel Gritzer
Add 2 cups of black bean filling, smoothing to an even layer. Save any remaining filling for another use.
Serious Eats / Daniel Gritzer
Gently form a top crust with remaining 1/3 masa, binding it with edge.
Serious Eats / Daniel Gritzer
Wipe any masa residue from rim of skillet. Bake tamale pie until cooked through and lightly golden on top, 45 minutes to 1 hour. Let cool slightly, then slice and serve, passing hot sauce and salsa verde at the table.
Serious Eats / Daniel Gritzer
Special Equipment
Stand mixer
,
blender
, 12-inch
cast iron skillet
or 3-quart
casserole dish
Notes
Masa harina para tamales (dried nixtamalized masa flour for tamales) is available at well-stocked grocers in the international or Latin foods aisle.
Any filling can be used in this pie; just substitute the beans here with two cups of a
Mexican braise
,
chili
, or stewed vegetables. If using a meat, make sure it is shredded or ground, since large chunks of meat won't make an even layer of filling.
